entry.title: Output using BRF+ for order confirmation
entry.content:
Output management in SAP S/4HANA governs the generation and distribution of business
documents, such as order confirmations, invoices, and delivery notes. With the advent of
S/4HANA, SAP introduced a new framework for output management leveraging the
Business Rule Framework Plus (BRF+), replacing the traditional NACE-based approach.
This new mechanism provides greater flexibility, improved user experience, and better
integration capabilities. Below is a comprehensive guide to configuring output
management for order confirmation using BRF+.
This documents provides a step by step guide to setup output using BRF+ for order
confirmation.
Step 1: Activate S/4HANA Output Management
Ensure that the output management functionality is activated in the system. This is done by
verifying the system configuration in SPRO:
Path: SPRO > Cross-Application Components > Output Control > Activate Output
Management.
Step 2: Define Output Types
Navigate to the relevant configuration to define output types for sales documents:
Path: SPRO > > Cross-Application Components > Output Control > Define Output Types.

Copy the standard and create new output

3: Assign output channels
Path: SPRO > > Cross-Application Components > Output Control > Assign Output
ChannelsCopyOUTPUT)

Step 4: Define Rules for Determination of Master Form Template
Path: SPRO > > Cross-Application Components > Output Control > Define Rules for
Determination

Click on new entries
And enter the details as below

Step 5: Assign Form Templates
Path: SPRO > > Cross-Application Components > Output Control > Assign Form
Tem

Organization ID = company code Org
unit Type = Sales Org (VKORG) Org
Unit ID= SAGR (Sales org)

Click on new entries and enter the below

Form Template: SD_SLS_ORDER_CONFIRM (Standard)
Step 6: Define Business rules for output Parameter determination
Path: SPRO > > Cross-Application Components > Output Control > Define Business rules
for Output Upon clicking on it new web page will be opened

Parameter determination Step1:
Determination

Click on Edit and add new

Sales Org 

Document Category C

Sales Order Type

Dispatch Time: 1 Immediate
Upon entering all the details, click on activate

Parameter determination Step2:
Determination Step: Receiver

Click on Edit and new entries
New row will be populated. Enter the valuesRole=o/p

Upon entering the details, click on activate

Output Parameter determination Step3: Determination
Step: Channel
Click & edit and new entries

No role is needed as we gave AG in Receiver

Upon entering the details click on activate

Output Parameter determination Step 4: Determination
step: printer settings

Click on edit and new entries 

Number of copies=1

Upon entering the details, click on activate

Output Parameters determination step 5:
Determination Step: Form Template 

Click on edit and click on ‚Äò+‚Äô new entries 

Upon entering all the detail like

Output type, Form template CLICK ON ACTIVATE

Output Parameters determination step 6:
Determination Step: Output Relevance 

Click on edit and click on ‚Äò+‚Äô add new entries. New row will be populated and add the
required entries

entry.title: Re: Error when querying a SAC story that consumes data fr...
entry.content:
Hi Miquel, 

since the story worked previously and you do not have more data, then the issue should not be in the data self, but one approach would be to suppress zeros, however SAC first loads all data and then applies zero suppresion, so a work-around is a dummy-dimension checking measures (not SAC dimension based on measures, but in DSP self) and suppressing zeros via the dummy-dimension. 

Also try a blank, empty story, where you re-create the table from the AM 1:1 to the original story self. Check if that works. Kind of base-line strip-down. If that works, the issue is in the original story self. Maybe there was an update of the SAC optimizer and you are using a feature which was de-optimized. If that does not work check the SAC Measurement Tool -> Client and Network tests, also do also check the ASSOCs you use, do persist those VIEWS as well (the ASSOC views). 

The SAC statistics can provide insight as well. I mean the background statistics, not the Analyze Story Performance in Runtime (I assume you already checked this one). MDS calls can be seen in the statistics including the SAC and browser time. 

Not sure what steps did you already check, maybe you can list out what / where was already done. 

Cheers, Martin

entry.title: Unlocking Scalability: How Apache Kafka Handles Massive Data Streams
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs data-driven world, applications must process massive volumes of information with low latency and near-perfect reliability. This is exactly where Apache Kafka shines. Often labeled as ‚Äújust a message queue,‚Äù Kafka is far more powerful. Its architecture is intentionally designed for horizontal scalability, enabling companies like LinkedIn, Netflix, Uber, and Airbnb to process trillions of events every single day.

This post breaks down how Kafka scales, focusing on three core mechanisms:

  • Topic Partitioning

  • Broker Clusters with Replication

  • Consumer Groups

Together, these form the foundation of Kafka‚Äôs ability to scale seamlessly.

1. The Power of Parallelism: Kafka Topic Partitioning

At the core of Kafka‚Äôs scalability is its partitioned log architecture.

A Kafka topic is divided into one or more partitions, and each partition is an ordered, immutable sequence of messages. This simple idea unlocks massive parallelism.

How Partitioning Works

  • Producers write to partitions based on a key or round-robin.

  • Consumers read partitions independently.

  • Kafka guarantees order only within a partition, not across the entire topic.

This means if you need strict ordering for a particular key (like userId), that key should always be routed to the same partition.

Why It Matters

Partitioning allows Kafka to:

  • scale horizontally across multiple brokers

  • process data in parallel

  • distribute workload efficiently across consumers

This is the foundational mechanism behind Kafka‚Äôs ability to scale linearly.

Visualizing Partitioning:

In Diagram 1, the user_events topic is split into P0, P1, and P2. A producer sends messages based on keys, and a consumer group reads them in parallel‚Äîeach consumer handling one or more partitions. This parallelism gives Kafka its first‚Äîand most important‚Äîdimension of scale.

Diagram 1

2. High Availability & Horizontal Growth: Broker Clusters and Replication

Kafka clusters are made up of brokers, and each topic partition is stored redundantly across them.

Leader‚ÄìFollower Model

  • Each partition has one leader replica

  • Other brokers store follower replicas

  • Producers and consumers communicate only with the leader

If a leader goes down, Kafka automatically promotes a fully synced follower to leader‚Äîusually within milliseconds.

In-Sync Replicas (ISR)

Replicas that are completely caught up with the leader are added to the ISR set.
Failover only happens within this ISR group, minimizing data loss risk.

Why Replication Matters

  • Prevents data loss

  • Enables zero-downtime failover

  • Helps scale reads

  • Adds durability and resiliency

Diagram 2 shows this setup clearly: multiple brokers, distributed replicas, and seamless failover‚Äîresulting in a system that can withstand broker crashes without downtime.

Diagram 2

 

 

 

3. Scaling Consumer Throughput with Consumer Groups 

Partitions decide how data is stored.
Consumer groups decide how data is consumed.

A consumer group consists of multiple consumers cooperating to consume data from a topic. Kafka‚Äôs enforced rule:

A partition can be consumed by only one consumer within a group.

This sets the upper limit on parallelism.

Parallelism Scenarios

PartitionsConsumersResult
101All data consumed by 1 consumer (slow)
1010Perfect parallelism (fast)
1011Extra consumer stays idle


If you need more throughput, you simply increase partitions OR add consumers‚Äîdepending on which side is the bottleneck.

Diagram 3  visually represents this: more partitions ‚Üí more potential parallelism ‚Üí more throughput.

Diagram 3

 

Real-World Scaling Examples

LinkedIn

Over 7 trillion messages/day
Uses Kafka for activity logs, real-time analytics, and fraud detection.

Netflix

Processes billions of events/day for:

  • device telemetry

  • QoS monitoring

  • recommender systems

Uber

Uses Kafka for:

  • real-time trip events

  • fare calculations

  • live map updates

These systems rely heavily on partitioning, replication, and consumer groups, the same principles discussed above.


Conclusion

Kafka‚Äôs scalability isn‚Äôt an accident‚Äîit‚Äôs baked into its core architecture. Through partitioning, broker clusters with replication, and consumer groups, Kafka achieves a remarkable blend of high throughput, resilience, and horizontal scalability.

Whether you're building real-time analytics pipelines, event-driven microservices, or large-scale data streaming platforms, understanding these mechanisms helps you design systems that can grow effortlessly‚Äîfrom thousands to trillions of events per day.


References & Further Reading

  1. Apache Kafka Documentation ‚Äî Architecture & Design
    https://kafka.apache.org/documentation/#design

  2. Confluent ‚Äî Kafka Fundamentals & Internals
    https://developer.confluent.io/learn-kafka/

  3. Spring for Apache Kafka
    https://spring.io/projects/spring-kafka

  4. Baeldung ‚Äî Kafka Architecture & Components
    https://www.baeldung.com/apache-kafka

entry.title: Re: Factory calendar related transactions
entry.content: The factory calendar in SAP affects any process that depends on working days, holidays, or date calculations. It influences scheduling in Production Planning (MRP runs, production orders), Plant Maintenance (maintenance plans and orders), and Sales & Distribution (delivery and transportation scheduling). It also impacts Purchasing (delivery dates, scheduling agreements), Warehouse Management (picking and goods movement planning), and Project System (network activity dates). In Finance, it affects payment runs and certain period-end processes. Essentially, any transaction that determines start or end dates, lead times, or capacity based on working days will rely on the assigned factory calendar.

entry.title: List View Customization in SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
Imagine walking into a library where every book is meticulously organized based on your interests and needs. Instead of wandering through endless rows of irrelevant titles, you find exactly what you‚Äôre looking for with ease. This is the transformative experience SAP Fieldglass Layout Manager now offers with its List View Support feature. Say hello to a new personalized experience!

 Customize Your View, Your Way

With the new List View Support in the Layout Manager, you can customize list view columns across essential modules like Job Postings, Work Orders, and Statements of Work. You‚Äôre in control, deciding which columns stay and which can be set aside. Some essential columns, the ones highlighted in blue, are automatically included for clarity and efficiency.

Why It Matters

Think of it as organizing a bookshelf adapted to your professional role. When you filter your view based on user roles, you focus directly on what‚Äôs relevant to your tasks. This approach lets users make informed decisions quickly, without getting stuck in unnecessary details.

 Ready to Curate Your SAP Experience?

Setting up your custom list view is as simple as arranging your favorite shelf. Organize your screen to reflect exactly what your role requires and keep the focus on the critical details.

To create a list view:

  1. Sign in to your SAP Fieldglass account
  2. Select Admin Configuration (gear icon)
  3. Select Layout Manager in the Configuration section
  4. Select New
  5. Enter a Name and an optional Description
  6. Choose List Views (Current Data) from the Type dropdown
  7. Choose the desired module from the Module dropdown

Then, add columns to your list view:

  1. Select Add Columns to add the desired columns
  2. Check the checkboxes for the columns you want to include and uncheck the ones you want to remove (Note: grayed out checkboxes cannot be removed)
  3. Select Add
  4. Select Add Module if you want to add another module
  5. Select Add to create your list view

Now, enjoy this personalized workspace, your own specially curated library within SAP Fieldglass.

entry.title: Re: FS813 ‚Äì ‚ÄúCompany code is not set up for OSS.‚Äù
entry.content:
Hello Martina,

Below is my step by step analysis.

 

TopicDetails
ErrorFS813 ‚Äì ‚ÄúCompany code XY is not set up for OSS.‚Äù
Where it occursDuring billing (SD Billing Document or Customer Invoice) using a tax code marked as OSS-relevant (fields OSS C/R, OSS Procedure).
Root Technical CauseBilling engine identifies the tax code as OSS-relevant ‚Üí checks OSS registration for the company code ‚Üí no OSS registration exists ‚Üí system stops processing with FS813.
Why the system thinks the tax code is OSS-relevantThe tax code includes OSS-related fields (OSS C/R, OSS Procedure), therefore triggering OSS logic.
Expected SAP Public Cloud behaviorOSS registration cannot be configured by customer. It must be configured by SAP in the backend (Global Tax Management).
What you cannot configureNo SSCUI, no CBC activity, no App for: ‚Ä¢ OSS registration ‚Ä¢ VAT OSS numbers ‚Ä¢ OSS tax determination ‚Ä¢ EU VAT regime setup ‚Ä¢ OSS procedures These settings are not exposed in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
What you can configureStandard tax code maintenance (Define Tax Codes), but OSS-specific fields are system-controlled and not editable.
Correct method to maintain OSS registration in Public CloudThrough SAP Support only ‚Äì SAP performs backend activation of OSS registration. Customer cannot maintain this manually.
Responsible SAP Support ComponentFIN-TAX-LOCAL-OSS (preferred) or LO-MD-FI-TAX
Information SAP requires to activate OSS‚Ä¢ Company code ‚Ä¢ Legal company name ‚Ä¢ OSS Registration Number (EU OSS VAT number) ‚Ä¢ List of OSS member states (EU countries where registration applies) ‚Ä¢ Valid-from date ‚Ä¢ Screenshot of FS813 ‚Ä¢ Affected tax code(s)
After SAP activationOSS registration is created in backend ‚Üí billing reprocesses successfully ‚Üí FS813 no longer appears.
When OSS must be activatedWhenever you use any tax code involving cross-border B2C EU VAT OSS logic (e-commerce, distance sales, electronic services, etc.).
Temporary Workaround (if billing must proceed immediately)‚Ä¢ Use a non-OSS tax code for the transaction. ‚Ä¢ Or duplicate the tax code but remove OSS C/R and OSS Procedure (if editable). ‚Ä¢ This bypasses OSS logic until SAP activates it.
Reason the customer cannot find configuration pointIn Public Cloud, OSS functionality is fully automated, and all OSS registration data sits in protected backend tables maintained only by SAP. Not accessible to customers via CBC/SSCUI.
Why OSS is system-controlledOSS is part of SAP Global Tax Service, which manages VAT registrations centrally to prevent compliance issues.
Link between Tax Code & OSS RegistrationTax code triggers OSS logic ‚Üí system expects OSS registration for company code ‚Üí missing data ‚Üí FS813.
Common scenarios where FS813 appears‚Ä¢ Tax code created by customer with OSS fields populated ‚Ä¢ SAP standard tax code includes OSS settings ‚Ä¢ Sales from EU country to another EU member state using B2C model ‚Ä¢ E-commerce or distance sales scenarios
Final Solution SummarySAP must activate OSS registration for your company code. Customer cannot do it inside the system. Raise SAP Support Ticket with details.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: SAP DM - Current Order in Line Monitor POD
entry.content:
Hi,

An order is current if the following conditions are met:

  1. The order is started
  2. The execution status is not completed
  3. The goods receipt quantity is less than the planned quantity

Additionally, here is how the default order is picked:

  1. First current order from the list of Active current orders
  2. If there is no current order, then no default is selected

Hope it helps! Br, Manoel

The problem is that when SYNC fails for document A ‚Üí exception is raised before it refreshes RESULT_TAB and RESULT_TAB remains polluted with A bad URL.

entry.title: Re: Letter Of Credit Thru GTS
entry.content:
Overview: A Letter of Credit (LC) is a secure payment instrument in international trade. From the exporter‚Äôs side, it ensures guaranteed payment once documents are correctly presented. From the importer‚Äôs side, it provides assurance that payment will only be made if goods are shipped as agreed.

 Business Process for Letter of Credit (LC)

Import Side (Buyer / Importer)
Sales Agreement: Importer and exporter agree on terms of trade (Incoterms, price, delivery, payment).

LC Application: Importer applies to their bank (issuing bank) for an LC in favor of the exporter.

Issuance of LC: Issuing bank sends the LC to the exporter‚Äôs bank (advising bank).

Shipment of Goods: Exporter ships goods according to contract terms.

Document Submission: Exporter submits required documents (invoice, bill of lading, insurance, packing list, etc.) to their bank.

Document Examination: Issuing bank checks documents against LC terms.

Payment: If documents comply, the bank releases payment to the exporter. Importer then receives goods.

Export Side (Seller / Exporter)

LC Receipt: Exporter receives LC via advising bank and verifies terms (amount, shipment date, documents required).

Shipment Preparation: Exporter arranges shipment, ensuring compliance with LC conditions.

Document Preparation: Exporter prepares and collects documents (commercial invoice, transport documents, certificate of origin, etc.).

Submission to Bank: Exporter submits documents to advising/negotiating bank.

Bank Review: Bank checks documents, forwards them to issuing bank.

Payment Collection: Once documents are accepted, exporter receives payment.

Key Points
Banks deal with documents, not goods ‚Äî payment depends on document compliance, not physical inspection.

Exporter‚Äôs risk is reduced : guaranteed payment if terms are met.

Importer‚Äôs risk is reduced: payment only made if goods are shipped as agreed.

Critical success factor: Accuracy in documentation. Even minor discrepancies can delay or block payment.

Example Flow
Importer in Bangladesh orders machinery from Germany.

Importer‚Äôs bank issues LC ‚Üí Exporter‚Äôs bank advises LC ‚Üí Exporter ships goods ‚Üí Provides documents ‚Üí Banks verify ‚Üí Payment released ‚Üí Goods delivered.

In short: For exporters, the LC is a payment guarantee. For importers, it is a performance guarantee. Both sides rely on banks as trusted intermediaries to reduce risk in cross-border trade Global Trade Management  SAP Global Trade Services connector for SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity

entry.title: Error encountered during MAIN_NEWBAS/PARRUN_BUSINESS_USER phase during conversion
entry.content:
Hi Folks,
 
During an In-Place conversion from ECC to S/4HANA on RISE using Software Update Manager (SUM), I encountered an error in the Postprocessing phase(MAIN_NEWBAS/PARRUN_BUSINESS_USER) that completely stopped the conversion. It is due to the RFC communication failures that halted the process during parallel execution phases.
The error message was:
Error during parallel execution of processes!
RFC system error during parallel execution of processes
Shortdump due to RFC communication failure
 
Problem Description-:
The SUM process failed with an RFC communication error. The logs (SAPupConsole.log) indicated:
  • RFC system error: [RFC_COMMUNICATION_FAILURE]
  • Shortdump in program SAPLARQ_HQV
  • Task: PDA:DB2:MAIN_NEWBASPARUPL_BUSINESS_USER
Moreover, the internal RFC destination (v_SID_00) for the application server is responding, but the fully qualified hostname (v***.s*p.cpr.cp**) redirects through an intermediate host/proxy. This redirection causes the parallelization framework's resource collector to fail when attempting to reach the internal RFC destination directly. The issue was caused by FQDN (Fully Qualified Domain Name) resolution behavior and cannot be modified via SM59.
 
 

 

 
SUM stopped due to RFC communication failure
 
 
Resolution
Since RFC cannot be modified via SM59., I applied a schema-level fix using hdbsql to change the destination of RFC from fully qualified name to * to allow dynamic resolution.
 
Steps Taken
  1. Connect to HANA Database
hdbsql -i <instance_number> -u <user> -p <password>
 
  1. Locate RFC Destinations SUM stores RFC destinations in the table:
    SAPUPRC.RFCDEST
  2. Backup the Table Always take a backup before making changes:
    SQL
    CREATE TABLE SAPUPRC.RFCDEST_BKP AS SELECT * FROM SAPUPRC.RFCDEST;
  3. Update RFCOPTIONS Replace FQDN with * to allow dynamic resolution:
    SQL
    UPDATE SAPUPRC.RFCDEST
    SET RFCOPTIONS = REPLACE(RFCOPTIONS, 'fqdn-hostname', '*')
    WHERE RFCDEST = 'vh*****_SID_00';
           OR
            update SCHEMA_USER.RFCDES set RFCOPTIONS=replace(RFCOPTIONS, 'd=2,7=60D9,7=60D9,',   'H=*,d=2,7=60D9,7=60D9,') where RFCDEST = 'vh*****i_SID_00'
 
 
I have tried to explain further with diagram -:
 

 

 
The diagram illustrates three scenarios related to RFC resolution during an SAP SUM upgrade/conversion:
 
Top Section: FQDN Redirection Causing RFC Failure
  • SUM ‚Üí RFC Destination ‚Üí FQDN ‚Üí Proxy ‚Üí App Server
  • Here, the RFC destination uses a Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN).
  • The FQDN resolves through an intermediate proxy, which SUM‚Äôs parallelization framework does not handle well.
  • This redirection leads to RFC communication failure during parallel processing.
 
Middle Section: Dynamic Resolution with *
  • SUM ‚Üí RFC Destination ‚Üí * ‚Üí App Server
  • When the RFC destination is changed to *, SUM uses dynamic resolution via the message server.
  • This bypasses the proxy and connects directly to the application server.
  • Result: Parallelization works successfully.
 
Bottom Section: Ideal Direct RFC Communication
  • SUM ‚Üí RFC Destination ‚Üí App Server
  • Represents the ideal scenario where RFC resolves directly to the application server without any proxy or intermediate hop.
 
 
Validation
  • Repeat the SUM phase at a point where it stopped.
  • Verified successful RFC communication.
 
Key Learnings
  • FQDN issues can break parallel processing.
  • Schema-level changes can resolve RFC failures when standard options are unavailable.
 
Conclusion
This workaround helped me resume the conversion successfully. If you face similar RFC issues during upgrades/conversion, this approach can save time and effort.

entry.title: Re: Billing Plan from Projects
entry.content:
Dear @Dinesh_158,

In Public Cloud the button only becomes active if all of these conditions are met:

Practical checklist for you.

On your system do this for one test order:

  1. Create / open a Project with Revenue ( Project Control ‚Äì Enterprise Projects (F3215))
  2. On a WBS:
    • Billing element = Yes

 

    • Create at least one milestone tab

 

    • Release the project/WBS.
  1. In Create/Change Sales Order:
    • Use a sales document + item category that supports billing plans.
    • In Account Assignment, enter the billing WBS

 

    • Go to Billing Plan tab ensure a milestone billing plan type is shown.
  1. Now check the button Create from Milestones again.

If ANY of these four things is missing (project not with revenue, WBS not a billing element, no milestones, item category without billing plan), the button will be grey.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/ee9ee0ca4c3942068ea584d2f929b5b1/e75fa6c1d2cc437abf1c1beda0097ef3.html?version=2508.00

 

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Discover the insights of your SAP BTP extension with SAP LeanIX
entry.content:
When joining SAP LeanIX in Q2 this year, the mission I was sent on was creating transparency on your custom-built applications and extensions on SAP BTP. As SAP LeanIX helps you not only to plan your landscape transformation, but as well to proactively identify and manage obsolete technology in your IT landscape, you need to have as much transparency as possible. That‚Äôs not only true for your standard software, but also the artefacts which make your company unique.

I‚Äôd like to bring together the story of what the great team I work with has provided throughout the year in the context of SAP BTP and combine it with what was already available in regard to self-build software, as all now comes together:

  • See what‚Äôs going on in SAP Build,
  • Know what has been deployed in SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment,
  • Dig into the tech stack of these deployments

See below how you can follow along.

Create an application with SAP‚Äôs Cloud Application Programming model

This is nothing new in the world of SAP BTP developers and inside this community. Thus, I simply followed https://developers.sap.com/tutorials/hana-cloud-cap-create-project..html which gave me an application based on https://cap.cloud.sap/docs/about/. Two things I did which are important for moving along:

  1. I synced the artifacts to github.com,
  2. I deployed the CAP application to SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry runtime.

Both should bring this closer to reality of non-tutorial-based developments. So far, for the typical SAP BTP consumer, this is an old hat, right? Therefore, I‚Äôd like to bring in the angle of the enterprise architects (EA), who want to see what custom applications are built and which technologies are being used, so that it‚Äôs easier to keep track of these details. This is where SAP LeanIX Application Portfolio Management (APM) comes into the picture.

Keep track easily

Your EAs want to keep track of what‚Äôs going in your company's technology stack. Continuing on the flow, connect your SAP Build instance which is used for production-related extensions to SAP LeanIX APM. This will provide you transparency on what SAP Build projects exist and will suggest modeling your SAP BTP account structure along LeanIX‚Äôs BTP modeling best practices.

The SAP Build Code project is suggested to being created as an ‚ÄúApplication‚Äù fact sheet. It is based on SAP Build Code, hence two related ‚ÄúIT Component‚Äù fact sheets are suggested. SAP BTP, your global account, and the subaccount are recommended as 3-leveled ‚ÄùPlatform‚Äù fact sheets. Let‚Äôs wait with its creation though.

While this is nice, it won‚Äôt give you any insights into the actual Cloud Foundry applications and the SAP BTP services you use. This is where you want to connect SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment of your global account to SAP LeanIX APM. The good news is that you only need to setup one integration per global account to APM and it will enable you to crawl all the Cloud Foundry spaces and organizations inside of it. As long as you use the same platform user + IAS certificate + password, the integration will fetch details about deployed applications and their bound SAP BTP services.

Following the above tutorial, the discovery inside my Cloud Foundry space looks like this:

Diving into one application, it reveals you

  • the deployed CF application,
  • if it‚Äôs part of a multi-target-application, the recommendation is creating a fact sheet for that too,
  • the bound SAP BTP services suggested as IT components
  • the Cloud Foundry buildpack including its version.

Go ahead and create the two ‚Äúapplication‚Äù fact sheets and the IT components. The fact sheet for the actual deployment will be of the subtype ‚ÄúMicroservice‚Äù and its MTA will be the ‚ÄúBusiness Application‚Äù subtype.

To combine the SAP Build Code ‚Äúapplication‚Äù fact sheet with the MTA, you can edit the suggested line item of the SAP Build Code discovery item to point to the MTA fact sheet. That will give you the transparency of the used SAP BTP services as part of your deployment and the SAP Build project details.

After creating the other two applications of the CF MTA to your inventory and linking it to the MTA-fact-sheet, you have the insights into your CF-based & SAP-Build-Code-created application:

Knowing the inside

This takes you already quite far when it comes to making your SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry deployments transparent for the enterprise architecture team. With this modeling, it‚Äôs easy to identify which applications across all deployments in BTP use which build pack version. Once the build pack ages, application owners can be asked to update.

This might not be enough though for mitigating technology risks and compliance upfront. An add-on to SAP LeanIX APM addresses exactly this gap. Let‚Äôs explore how to extend the above use case with SAP LeanIX Technology Risk and Compliance.

Add the Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) to the mix

‚ÄúSoftware Bill of Materials (SBOM) files play a vital role in managing and understanding dependencies among microservices. These files, typically adhering to the widely-used System Package Data Exchange (SPDX) or CycloneDX format, provide a comprehensive inventory of all software components, libraries, and modules used by a microservice.‚Äù (source)

Let‚Äôs blend these into the above Node.js tutorial. For the three deployments, I used CycloneDX to generate three individual SBOMs (there are more open source tools to check out):

  • for ‚ÄúMyHANAApp-srv‚Äù one in the folder ‚Äúgen/srv‚Äù,
  • for ‚ÄúMyHANAApp-db-deployer‚Äù in ‚Äúgen/db‚Äù, and
  • for ‚ÄúMyHANAApp‚Äù in ‚Äúapp/router‚Äù.

In the end, the mta.yaml tells you where to generate these SBOMs. Run cyclonedx-npm -o sbom.json in each folder to store the SBOMs in separate JSON files. After setting up your LeanIX workspace for the self-build software use case, you can push it to the fact sheets of each application created beforehand with the path:

https://{SUBDOMAIN}.leanix.net/services/technology-discovery/v1/factSheets/{factSheetId}/sboms

The exact details are well documented. Pushing these to your fact sheets will give you insights into which libraries and frameworks are being used inside every application (see details in the tech stack discovery documentation). This allows you to proactively address technical risks. Here is how it looks like for the above ‚ÄúMyHANAApp‚Äù in the LeanIX relations explorer:

It blends the SAP BTP services, the used Cloud Foundry buildpack, and used libraries inside the deployment. All the details of the Node.js dependencies can be listed in the SBOM explorer:

Mission accomplished

That‚Äôs it. It‚Äôs quite a bit indeed, but now I have the full insight into

  • where did I create the CF MTA app,
  • where is the app deployed, and
  • which tech stack is this built on.

For regular updates of the SBOMs, you can integrate their generation and push to the API endpoints in your CI/CD pipeline. For CI/CD, use the SAP BTP CI/CD service or create a Github-actions-based flow and the transparency of your tech stack will stay up-to-date.

Let me know of your comments and feedback here in the community! The team and I are now looking into the same storyline for SAP BTP, Kyma runtime. Furthermore, I want to bring in the transformation flow for classical on-stack extensions.

For both, I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts!

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud V2 Sales Quotation : October 2025 Edition
entry.content:
October brings a fresh set of improvements to help you work smarter with Sales Quotes. This release brings a set of powerful improvements that make creating, managing, and updating quotes smoother than ever. Whether you are a sales rep looking to work faster or an admin trying to simplify configuration, these updates are designed to remove friction and support real-world quoting scenarios.

1. Item-Level Ship-To for Sales Quotes

You can now manage shipping information with much more precision. A dedicated Ship-To field at the line-item level allows each product in a quote to be shipped to a different location when needed.

Key Capabilities

  • Each line item gets its own Ship-To assignment, giving full flexibility for multi-destination shipments.

  • New items automatically inherit the header-level Ship-To, while still allowing overrides.

  • Complete Ship-To details, such as address, contact info, and more, are visible right at the item level.

Why It Matters

Sales reps gain greater control and accuracy when working with customers who operate across multiple locations. This leads to cleaner quotes and a smoother customer experience thanks to precise, per-item shipping options.

Getting Started

Use adaptation to add the Parties section to the product line item detail view 

 

 

2. Configurable Default Durations for Quote Dates

You now have full control over how key quote dates behave. Instead of relying on fixed system logic, admins can define their own default durations for both Quote Validity End and Requested Date.

Key Capabilities

  • Configure the default duration for Quote Validity End (e.g., creation date + X days).

  • Configure the default duration for Requested Date in the same flexible way.

  • System behavior now aligns with your business rules and not hard-coded values.

Why It Matters

Organizations can tailor date defaults to match their sales cycles and customer expectations. Reps get consistent, predictable date behavior without manual adjustments, reducing errors and speeding up quote creation.

Getting Started

Navigate to Settings ‚Üí Sales Quotes ‚Üí General to define your preferred default durations for Validity End and Requested Date.

 

3. Mass Edit Capability in Sales Quotes

Sales reps can now bulk-update multiple quotes in one action, making large-volume quote management faster and more efficient.

Key Capabilities

  • Sales reps can now select multiple quotes directly from the Sales Quote List view and update shared fields in a single action.

  • Updates are applied simultaneously across all selected quotes, eliminating the need to open each document individually.

Business Benefit

  • Simplifies management of large quote volumes, improving workflow efficiency.

  • Saves significant time by replacing repetitive single-quote edits with one consolidated update.

Getting Started

  • This capability is available by default in the Sales Quote List view.

4. Registered Products in Sales Quotes

Sales reps can now directly search and add registered products to the assets a customer already owns right inside the quote. And when a quote is created from a case, its registered products are automatically copied over, giving you a head start.

Why it matters

This enhancement makes it much easier to build quotes based on existing customer assets. Reps spend less time searching and more time preparing the right offer, with accurate context from the start.

Getting Started

Use adaptation to add the Registered Products section to the quote detail view, and begin selecting customer-owned assets as part of your quoting process.

 

5. Sales Quote APIs Now Live on SAP Business Accelerator Hub

Developers and partners can now access the Sales Quote APIs directly from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, making it simpler to integrate, automate, or extend quoting processes across systems. Link for direct access Sales Quote Service

Why it matters:
It opens the door for deeper integration scenarios, smoother data flows, and more flexible custom solutions.

 

Wrap-Up

Whether it‚Äôs faster updates, smarter defaults, or better alignment with assets and shipping locations, each feature aims to simplify the sales process and deliver greater value to your teams.

We release updates every month to continuously enhance your experience. To see what we shipped last month, check out this  

Master Blog

entry.title: Important Update: Review Onboarding User Permissions
entry.content:
Dear Onboarding Partners and Customers,

We have an important update for you.

As previously mentioned in https://me.sap.com/notes/3196136, in early releases of SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding, Employee Central HRIS OData API permissions were required to view new hire data in Manage Pending Hire (MPH).

However, these permissions are no longer required for Onboarding. Please review your permission roles and remove these permissions from the Onboarding end-user roles. They are intended only for technical users for integration purposes, as highlighted in https://me.sap.com/notes/3594795.

Permissions to Check

Under Employee Central API, the following permissions should NOT be granted to end users:

  • Employee Central Foundation SOAP API
  • Employee Central Foundation OData API (read-only)
  • Employee Central Foundation OData API (editable)

Why This Matters

If these permissions are granted to end users:

  • When migrating to Latest People Profile ‚Äì Full Profile, more fields will be visible to the user than expected, which can lead to data exposure risks.
  • These permissions were previously needed for Onboarding but are now only required for technical users managing integrations.

Key Actions needed at your end

  •   Audit your Onboarding permission roles.
  •   Remove technical API permissions from end-user roles.

Thank you for your continued partnership and commitment to best practices. Keeping permissions aligned with current guidelines helps maintain data security and ensures a smooth experience for all users.

entry.title: Re: Delivery from a different plant than production in Ma...
entry.content:
Managing KMAT items in SAP is complex and you need someone with good expertise in variant configuration and also costing (PP and CO aspects of the scenario). When you create a sales order, you will assign characteristics for variant configurable item which will be passed on to corresponding production order too. When production is done, the stock is assigned to sales order. As sick is assigned to sales order (item category X or E), you cannot use stock transfer (stock in transit uses the same field of item category). Hence sales order assigned stock cannot be used for stock transfer. Solution is to create a material master - variant item for the configurable material with required characteristics and use this item in sales order. The entire scenario is more complex as you need moving the stock to another country too which requires export and import relevant conditions too and managing the costing is more complex. PP. SD and CO consultants should sit together and try the complete scenario in SAP. 

If you create variant material, you can also try procurement type in MRP 4 view in plant B ( stock transfer from another plant).. in this case, of you create sales order in plant B (delivery from B), MRP creates stock transfer from A.. In the material master for plant A, you define it for indoor production. MRP in A creates planned order/production order thanks to stick transfer reservation from plant B. Once produced you can stick transport to plant B.

entry.title: üí° The Architect's Blueprint: Unifying Commerce for Business Growth
entry.content:
Our primary mission is to solve the endemic problem of fragmented customer experiences. When disparate systems‚Äîsales, inventory, and marketing‚Äîoperate in silos, we lose sight of the customer, resulting in wasted budget and missed opportunities. This blueprint outlines the strategic use of the SAP technology stack to achieve true Unified Commerce, providing value not just to the business, but also clear direction for our technical teams.

1. The Foundation: Customer Identity and Trust

Business Problem: We can't personalize experiences or comply with global privacy regulations without a single, reliable customer record.

Component: SAP Customer Data Cloud (CDC)

  • Architectural Role: This is our Identity and Trust Hub. It must be the authoritative System of Record for customer identity and consent.

  • Developer Focus: CDC performs Profile Unification, aggregating data across all channels into one golden record. It manages mandatory Consent Management Platform (CMP) functions, ensuring that all data activation is compliant.

  • Integration Strategy: A crucial, high-priority Profile Sync pipeline sends unified, consented customer profiles and real-time behavioral data directly to SAP Emarsys for activation. This is the bedrock of our personalization strategy.

2. The Front Door: Experience and Transaction

Business Problem: Customers demand instant, seamless experiences across all touchpoints with flexible, reliable payment options.

Component: SAP Commerce Cloud

  • Architectural Role: The API-First Front Office. It's responsible for the user experience, product catalog, and pricing. The built-in AI features enable natural language shopping queries, improving conversion rates.

  • Payment Strategy (OPF): We mandate the use of the Open Payment Framework (OPF).

    • The Value: The OPF serves as a standardized adapter layer, abstracting sensitive payment logic away from the core. This allows our teams to integrate seamlessly with various Third-Party Payment Providers (PSPs) for flexible payment options, while minimizing PCI compliance scope on the Commerce platform itself.

3. The Digital Core and Integration Strategy

Business Problem: The customer experience fails if the back office is not reliable (e.g., incorrect inventory). We need resilient, real-time connectivity between sales and fulfillment.

Core Components: SAP S/4HANA & SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

  • SAP S/4HANA (The Digital Core): This is the transactional back-end, handling Order Fulfillment, Logistics, and Inventory. Its real-time architecture is vital for providing accurate inventory checks to Commerce.

  • SAP BTP Integration Suite: This is the Architectural Glue and Integration Layer.

    • Developer Focus: All cross-system data exchange is managed here using iFlows. This enforces the Clean Core Principle‚Äîwe do not modify core S/4HANA code for integration.

    • Key Integration: The high-volume Order Sync (Commerce to S/4HANA) is orchestrated through the Integration Suite, ensuring reliable, guaranteed delivery and a unified order history.

4. The Intelligence Layer: Activation and Personalization

Business Problem: Marketing spend must be targeted, relevant, and based on the most accurate customer profile to maximize Customer Lifetime Value (CLV).

Component: SAP Emarsys Marketing & Campaign Management

  • Architectural Role: The Unified Activation Platform. It consolidates all campaign planning, email execution, and personalization into a single system.

  • Developer/Architect Focus: Emarsys receives the high-fidelity, consented profiles from CDC. It serves as the orchestration engine for multi-wave, AI-powered campaigns, utilizing real-time triggers based on customer behavior.

üéØ Conclusion: Strategic Mandates for Technical Teams

This blueprint provides the stability and scalability required for business growth. For the developer and architect community, the mandate is clear:

  1. Enforce the Clean Core: All integrations must run through the SAP BTP Integration Suite.

  2. Profile Consistency: Ensure all systems read and write customer identity and consent data via SAP CDC.

  3. Future-Proof Payments: Utilize the OPF in Commerce to ensure a flexible, compliant payment architecture.

Following this structure ensures we deliver not just a functional solution, but a scalable, maintainable enterprise architecture.

entry.title: Re: From Exploration to Excellence: Maturity Assessment for SAP BTP
entry.content:
Thanks so much for sharing your thoughts and for bringing this question to the discussion, @Wallace!

Yes, it is perfectly fine for different roles within an organization to take the maturity assessment multiple times. To consolidate divergent views and ratings, we are actively planning features for collaboration and versioning as part of our future roadmap*.

entry.title: Can I change a connection's idle timeout after the connection has been established?
entry.content:
I know I can set idle timeout at the server level, and at the connection level when establishing a connection.  I have a customer that wants to set idle timeout depending on who is logged on.  I only know who is logged on once the logon user is authenticated, and thus a connection is established.  Therefore it is too late to use the connection parameter to set that user's idle timeout.  

Ideally, once a user's connection is established, I would read what their idle timeout should be and "make it so".  

Is this possible?  

Thanks!

entry.title: Re: Currency Conversion in Multi level / Multi Market Pri...
entry.content:
Solution 1: Market-Based Currency Segmentation

Due to SAP CPQ‚Äôs constraint that each market can be associated with only one currency, the straightforward approach is to create one market per region, each configured with its leading currency. While this setup aligns with CPQ‚Äôs standard architecture, it introduces significant overhead:
  • Requires maintaining multiple pricebooks ‚Äî one per market-currency combination.
  • Increases complexity in managing price updates and ensuring consistency across markets.
  • Becomes difficult to scale and audit as the number of markets grows.

Solution 2: Quote-Level Currency Selection with Custom Pricing

In a previous project involving SAP CPQ integrated with Salesforce (SFDC), we implemented a more scalable solution using custom pricing logic:
  • A quote-level custom field was introduced to allow users to select the desired currency for the quote.
  • Upon adding items to the quote, a quote script dynamically updated item prices based on the selected currency.
  • Instead of relying on standard pricebooks, custom tables were used to store base prices and exchange rates.
  • The pricing was handled entirely via custom pricing, allowing flexibility and reducing the need for multiple pricebooks.
This approach significantly reduced administrative overhead and improved maintainability, especially in multi-currency environments.
